knowledge_graph.title: Toffee
knowledge_graph.description: Toffee is an English confection made by caramelizing sugar or molasses along with butter, and occasionally flour. The mixture is heated until its temperature reaches the hard crack stage of 149 to 154 °C. While being prepared, toffee is sometimes mixed with nuts or raisins.

related_questions.question: Is toffee basically caramel?
related_questions.snippet: Ingredients: Toffee consists of sugar and butter, while caramel comprises sugar, water, and cream—or just sugar. Temperature: Confectioners cook toffee to the hard-crack stage, around 310 degrees Fahrenheit, resulting in its signature craggy shards.
related_questions.title: Toffee vs. Caramel: What Are the Differences? - 2024 - MasterClass

related_questions.question: What the heck is toffee?
related_questions.snippet: Toffee is a hard candy made mainly with sugar and butter. In America, the term "English toffee" is generally used for toffee prepared with a coating of chocolate and almonds.
related_questions.title: English Toffee - Recipe File - Cooking For Engineers

related_questions.question: What is toffee called in America?
related_questions.snippet: The English toffee eaten with regularity in America is also called buttercrunch. What's the difference? Primarily, the difference rests in the ingredients. Toffee in Britain is made with brown sugar, whereas buttercrunch is made with white granulated sugar.
related_questions.title: The History of English Butter Toffee - Woody Candy Company

related_questions.question: What is the difference between caramel and toffee sauce?
related_questions.snippet: The difference between caramel and toffee is greater, as caramel has a more liquid consistency and is usually pure sugar (it doesn't contain butter or flour). Still, the taste of caramel, fudge, and toffee is relatively similar, as they are all made from mostly sugar (as well as butter in the case of fudge and toffee).
related_questions.title: What's the difference between caramel, fudge, and toffee?

buttons.subtitle: What Is Toffee Made Of?
buttons.title: Toffee - Wikipedia
buttons.snippet: Toffee is an English confection made by caramelizing sugar or molasses (creating inverted sugar) along with butter, and occasionally flour. The mixture is heated until its temperature reaches the hard crack stage of 149 to 154 °C (300 to 310 °F). While being prepared, toffee is sometimes mixed with nuts or raisins.
snippet_highlighted_words: caramelizing sugar or molasses (creating inverted sugar) along with butter, and occasionally flour

buttons.subtitle: How Toffee Is Made
buttons.title: How to make toffee - BBC Good Food
buttons.snippet: Toffee is made from sugar mixed with milk, butter or cream plus an ingredient such as lemon juice or golden syrup to stop it crystallising. The mixture is heated to between 140C and 154C ('soft crack' stage and 'hard crack' stage), then allowed to cool and set.
snippet_highlighted_words: sugar mixed with milk, butter or cream plus an ingredient such as lemon juice or golden syrup to stop it crystallising
